review.title: \"Uber die Klassifizierung von Knoten in dynamischen Netzwerken mit Inhalt
review.abstract: This paper explains the DYCOS-Algorithm as it was introduced in by Aggarwal and Li in 2011. It operates on graphs whichs nodes are partially labeled and automatically adds missing labels to nodes. To do so, the DYCOS algorithm makes use of the structure of the graph as well as content which is assigned to the node. Aggarwal and Li measured in an experimental analysis that DYCOS adds the missing labels to a Graph with 19396 nodes of which 14814 are labeled and another Graph with 806635 nodes of which 18999 are labeld on one core of an Intel Xeon 2.5 GHz CPU with 32 G RAM within less than a minute. Additionally, extensions of the DYCOS algorithm are proposed.
histories: in German. This term paper was handed in on 17.01.2014
review.COMMENTS: in German. This term paper was handed in on 17.01.2014

metadata.title: Über die Klassifizierung von Knoten in dynamischen Netzwerken mit textuellen Inhalten

sections.text: 1 About the Classification of Nodes in Dynamic Networks with ContentsMartin ThomaSummary - In this paper, the DYCOS algorithm as presented in [AL11] is explained. It works on graphs whose nodes are partially labeled, and adds automatic labels for nodes that do not yet have labels. This process is called "classification," using the structure of the graph and textual information associated with the nodes. Experimental analysis described in [AL11] showed that even on dynamic graphs with 19,396 and 806 635 nodes, of which only 14,814 and 18,999 were labeled, it can run on a core of an Intel Xeon 2.5 GHz CPU in less than a minute.

sections.heading: 32 G RAM ausgeführt werden kann. Zusätzlich wird [AL11] kritisch Erörtert und und es werden mögliche Erweiterungen des DYCOS-Algorithmus vorgeschlagen.
sections.text: Keywords: DYCOS, label propagation, node classification

sections.heading: I. EINLEITUNG
sections.text: In the following, section I-A presents some examples in which the DYCOS algorithm could be applied. In section I-B, the problem definition is formally defined and in section I-C, special challenges of the task definition are dealt with.

sections.heading: A. Motivation
sections.text: Partially labeled graphs are ubiquitous. Publication databases with publications as nodes, references and quotations as edges and user-assigned labels (so-called tags) or categories as node labels; Wikipedia with articles as nodes, links as edges and categories as node labels as well as social networks with user properties as node labels are three examples of this. Often, node labels are only partially available and it is desirable to fill in the missing node labels automatically.

sections.heading: B. Problemstellung
sections.text: Node labels are now searched for all nodes that have not yet been labeled. Definition 1 (node classification problem) Be Gt = (Vt, Et, VL, t) a directed graph, where Vt denotes the set of all nodes, Et Vt · Vt the edge set and VL, t'Vt the set of described nodes at the time t. Also, Lt is the set of all labels assigned at the time t and f: VL, t ² Lt is the function that maps a node to its label. Furthermore, for each node v ² V a (possibly empty) text set T (v) is given. Labels for Vt\ VL, t ² Lt, also f: Vt\ VL, the task, are now searched.

sections.heading: C. Herausforderungen
sections.text: The graphs for which this algorithm was designed are many 10,000 nodes large and dynamic. "Dynamic" means in this context that new nodes and possibly also new edges can be added or edges or nodes can be removed. In addition, textual content is available for the nodes that can be used in the classification. In case of small changes, not everything should have to be calculated again, but based on previously authorized node labels, the classification should be adapted.

sections.heading: II. RELATED WORK
sections.text: Both the problem of node classification and that of text classification has already been analysed in different contexts, but so far it seems to be either the structure of the underlying graph or only the properties of the texts used. Thus, in [BCM11], [SJ01], among other things, methods for node classification are described, which are described like the DYCOS algorithm presented in [AL11], which is the subject of this elaboration, also based on random paths.Although there are also some papers on text classification [ZG02], [JCSZ10], none of them deal with the specific case of text classification with an underlying graph.The given methods for text classification also vary greatly. There are procedures based on the bagof words model [costelle12] how it is classified.

sections.heading: IV. ANALYSE DES DYCOS-ALGORITHMUS
sections.text: It is important for the DYCOS algorithms that they are able to take care of themselves. (DYCOS) The DYCOS algorithms are able to take care of themselves. (DYS) The DYS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DDDDDDS-DCS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-DDCS-CS-CS-CS-CS-DDCS-CS-CS-DCS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-CS-DDDCS-CS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DDDS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DDCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DDCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DCS-DC

sections.heading: V. PROBLEME DES DYCOS-ALGORITHMUS
sections.text: When applying the algorithm presented in [AL11] to real data sets, two problems could occur, which will be explained in the following. Furthermore, improvements are proposed, which still need to be investigated.

sections.heading: A. Anzahl der Knotenbeschriftungen
sections.text: The way the DYCOS algorithm was introduced, only graphs with a maximum of one label can be edited. However, in many cases, such as Wikipedia with categories as node labels, nodes have many labels. At first glance, this weakness is easy to fix, since counting the node labels counts every label for each node. Then, there is the question of how many labels the affected node should be labeled with. However, in Wikipedia articles, for example, a hierarchy is defined on the node. Thus, the category "classification method" is a subcategory of "classification." When categorizing articles, specific categories are absolutely preferable, and one cannot simply count for this category as well as for the category "classification."

sections.heading: B. Überanpassung und Reklassifizierung
sections.text: Aggarwal and Li do not describe in [AL11] to which node the classification algorithm should be applied. However, the order of the classification is relevant. In addition, the following minimum example: Given a dynamic graph without textual content. At the time t = 1, this graph has exactly one node v1 and v1 is labeled with A. At the time t = 2, an unlabeled node v2 and the edge (v2, v1) are added. Now, the DYCOS algorithm is applied to this node and v2 is labeled with A. At the time t = 3, a node v3 is added, which was written with B6 v1 A v2 t = 1 (a) Av2 At = 2 (b) t = 2v1 Av2 Av2 Av2 Av3 Bt = 3 (c) t = 3v1 Av2 Av2 Av3 V3 Bv4t = 3 (d) = 4Figure 2: Minimal example V2 Av2 V3 (V3).

metadata.abstractText: Zusammenfassung—In dieser Arbeit wird der DYCOSAlgorithmus, wie er in [AL11] vorgestellt wurde, erklärt. Er arbeitet auf Graphen, deren Knoten teilweise mit Beschriftungen versehen sind und ergänzt automatisch Beschriftungen für Knoten, die bisher noch keine Beschriftung haben. Dieser Vorgang wird „Klassifizierung“ genannt. Dazu verwendet er die Struktur des Graphen sowie textuelle Informationen, die den Knoten zugeordnet sind. Die in [AL11] beschriebene experimentelle Analyse ergab, dass er auch auf dynamischen Graphen mit 19 396 bzw. 806 635 Knoten, von denen nur 14 814 bzw. 18 999 beschriftet waren, innerhalb von weniger als einer Minute auf einem Kern einer Intel Xeon 2.5 GHz CPU mit 32 G RAM ausgeführt werden kann. Zusätzlich wird [AL11] kritisch Erörtert und und es werden mögliche Erweiterungen des DYCOS-Algorithmus vorgeschlagen.
